On June 15th, six countries were added to this list: 
Italy (except for Emilia Romagna, Lombardy and Piemonte)
France (except for Ile de Frace)
Spain (except for Madrid, Catalonia, Castilla -La Mancha, Castile and Leon)
Poland (except for Katowice Airport)
Greece
Croatia

Israel was originally included on the list but is now removed.

description:
23 Feb 2020
The Maltese health authorities are implementing all the necessary preparedness and response actions required for the outbreak of COVID-19. Screening is being enhanced by introducing thermal screening at points of entry. During this coming week, thermal screening cameras will be installed at the Malta International Airport, whereby ALL inbound passengers will be screened. This will also be implemented in cruise liner and catamaran terminals.

February 24, the health authorities announced that all passengers arriving in Malta were screened by thermal cameras. Two thermal scanning devices were installed in Malta International Airport. Passengers disembarking from vessels at the Grand Harbour and catamaran terminal in Marsa were also scanned. At Mater Dei Hospital, all patients with respiratory symptoms were checked for COVID-19.

On the 25th February 2020, the Maltese Health Authorities expanded surveillance on people returning from China, Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan, Iran, South Korea, Northern part of Italy – Lombardy, Piedmont, Veneto and Emilia-Romagna.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
target_province: Northern part of Italy – Lombardy, Piedmont, Veneto and Emilia-Romagna

description: On the 25th February 2020, the Ministry for Health announced that Malta is still in a pre-containment phase. A public health strategy is aimed at training first responders. The Department also has additional contingency plans in the event that the situation aggravates beyond the current situation in Europe and locally.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From the 12th of March 2020, The Law Enforcement Agency will deliver a two-month medicine stock to elderly people enrolled in the Pharmacy of Your Choice scheme in Malta.

On the 2nd March 2020, Maltese health authorities began performing laboratory testing for the COVID-19 virus for patients suffering from acute respiratory tract infection with sudden onset of cough, fever or shortness of breath and who have been in countries and regions where local transmission of COVID-19 has been reported:

Western Pacific Region: China (incl. Hong Kong), South Korea, Japan, Singapore, Australia, Malaysia, Vietnam.

European Region: Italy, France, Germany, Spain, United Kingdom, Norway, Croatia, Netherlands, San Marino.

South-East Asian Region: Thailand.

Eastern Mediterranean Region: Iran, United Arab Emirates.

Region of the Americas: Canada, United States of America.
target_country: Australia,Canada,China,Croatia,France,Germany,Iran,Italy,Japan,Malaysia,Netherlands,Norway,San Marino,Singapore,South Korea,Spain,Thailand,United Arab Emirates,United Kingdom,United States,Vietnam
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On the 3rd of April 2020, the Superintendent of Public Healh ordered that non-essential travel to be banned between Malta and Gozo. Essental travel includes: traveling to and from work, travel to visit family members,travel for medical reasons, travel to visit family in hospital.

On the 3rd of April 2020, the Superintendent of Public Health ordered that non-essential travel to be banned between Malta and Gozo. Essential travel includes: travelling to and from work, travel to visit family members, travel for medical reasons, travel to visit family in the hospital. On the 4th of May 2020, the Superintendent of Public Health has revoked the travel ban between Malta and Gozo.

On the 26th March Malta announced it will impose a mandatory lockdown on vulnerable individuals commencing on 28th March. This group includes those who are: over 65 years old; pregnant; with chronic illness; insulin-dependent diabetics; biological medication; had chemotherapy in last six months; had a transplant or HIV treatment; on renal dialysis; respiratory problems who needed treatment in last year; cardiac problems in last six months; on oral steroids.
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

On June 4th, the Maltese Government announced vulnerable people will be able to go out as of June 5th.

description: On the 27th March 2020 the Ministry for the Family, Children's Rights and Social Solidarity in Malta established a 24/7 mental health hotline with a focus on reaching children.
type_text: A mental health hotline targeted at children. Professional social workers will be hearing, empathising and give advice to people feeling lonely or in a great state of desolation.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On the 9th April 2020, the Maltese Government began a voluntary repatriation assistance scheme for all foreign nationals. The scheme is aimed at all foreign nationals, who either resided or who were here on a temporary visit, and who wish to be repatriated to their home country.
Assistance is also available to European Union citizens and third-country nationals who have been staying in Malta for different purposes such as employment, education and family reasons, among others. Foreign individuals who are not in possession of a residence document are also entitled to assistance.
type_text: The Maltese Government is subsidising flights to help foreign nationals fly back to their home country in case they are stuck in Malta. The Maltese government had previously helped individuals from Italy, Spain, France, Germany and Switzerland who were stranded in Malta due to flight closures fly back home. They are now extending the help to people from other countries who are also stuck in Malta.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Maltese Health Authorities recommend anyone arriving from China, Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan, Iran, South Korea and the Northern part of Italy to self-quarantine for fourteen days.

From the 25th of February 2020, Maltese Health Authorities recommend anyone arriving from China, Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan, Iran, South Korea and the Northern part of Italy to self-quarantine for fourteen days. From the 27th of February onwards self-quarantine is mandatory.
On the 27th of Febuary, Malta announces a mandatory self quarantnie for travellers from Italy, China (including Hong Kong), Singapore, Japan, Iran, or South Korea.

On the 27th of Febuary, Malta announces a mandatory self quarantnie for travellers from Italy, China (including Hong Kong), Singapore, Japan, Iran, or South Korea. From 11th of March Maltese police will enforce a mandatory quarantine for travellers returning from China, Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan, Iran, South Korea, Italty, Switzerland, Germany, France, Spain.

On the 11th of March, Malta announced mandatory quarantine for travellers returning from China, Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan, Iran, South Korea, Italty, Switzerland, Germany, France, Spain. €1,000, enforced by police.

On the 11th of March, Malta announced mandatory quarantine for travellers returning from China, Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan, Iran, South Korea, Italty, Switzerland, Germany, France, Spain. €1,000, enforced by police.

description: On Monday the 16th March 2020 the Maltese Government announced that starting from Tuesday 17th March at 11:59 pm, all bars (excluding takeaway), restaurants (excluding delivery), gymnasiums, clubs, cinemas and tombola halls must remain closed.

On Monday the 16th March 2020 the Maltese Government announced that starting from Tuesday 17th March at 11:59 pm, all bars (excluding takeaway), restaurants (excluding delivery), gymnasiums, clubs, cinemas and tombola halls must remain closed.

On March 16, The Maltese Government has announced more measures upon the recommendations of health authorities. With effect from Tuesday 17 March at 11:59pm, all bars (excluding take-away), restaurants (excluding deliveries), gymnasiums, clubs, cinemas and tombola halls must remain closed.

description:
Since March 23, non-essential retail was stopped. This includes outlets selling clothes, jewellery, toys, videogames, books, electronics and household goods, among others. Excluded from this prohibition are supermarkets, bakeries, groceries and pet shops, among others. Non-essential services will also be stopped. This includes hairdressers, beauticians and tattooists, among others. Excluded from this prohibition are postal services, medical services, transport services and banks. With effect from Monday 4th May 2020, some commercial establishments will be allowed to open once again. These include:
Lotto Shops
VRT Testing Centres
Clothes Shops
Sport Shops
Jewellery Shops (even Costume Jewellery)
Shoe Shops
Haberdashery
Discount Stores
Luggage and Travel Shops
Toys
Hobby Shops
Florists
Furniture Shops
Perfumeries
Opticians

On the 10th of March 2020, Malta announces restrictions on mass events. Outdoor events of more than 2000 people are banned. Indoor events limited to 750 people.

On 30th of March 2020, Maltese Government announced public gatherings will be limited to 3 people. Police empowered to issue fines of €100 per person in the group. The measure will not apply to bus stops and queues but social distancing rules of a minimum two metres will apply. Family members from the same household will not incur fines if gathering outside in group larger than 3.
enforcer: Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)
